abstract: Prudential of Britain’s audacious $35.5 billion offer for the Asian life insurance business of the American International Group is reminiscent of pre-crisis mega-deals.

lead_paragraph: Insurance is supposed to be about protecting against risk. Try telling that to Prudential of Britain, whose audacious $35.5 billion offer for the Asian life insurance business of the American International Group is reminiscent of pre-crisis mega-deals. The takeover will more than double the size of Prudential and make it the most comprehensive pan-Asian insurer. Transformational indeed, but Prudential will have to convince investors that it has not stretched too far.

headline.main: An Insurance Bid That Invites Risk

abstract: No financial reform is better than a weak reform that would only create a false sense of security then fail in the clinch, Paul Krugman writes in his latest Op-Ed in The New York Times.
snippet: No financial reform is better than a weak reform that would only create a false sense of security then fail in the clinch, Paul Krugman writes in his latest Op-Ed in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: So here’s the situation. We’ve been through the second-worst financial crisis in the history of the world, and we’ve barely begun to recover: 29 million Americans either can’t find jobs or can’t find full-time work. Yet all momentum for serious banking reform has been lost. The question now seems to be whether we’ll get a watered-down bill or no bill at all. And I hate to say this, but the second option is starting to look preferable, Paul Krugman writes  in The New York Times.

headline.main: For Financial Reform, an Endgame, or Just the End?

abstract: In his annual letter to shareholders, Warren Buffett took a shot at Wall Street and the incentive system for corporate “advice” on deals.
snippet: In his annual letter to shareholders, Warren Buffett took a shot at Wall Street and the incentive system for corporate “advice” on deals.
lead_paragraph: Warren Buffet’s annual letter did more than just review how business went last year for Berkshire Hathaway, it took a shot at the fees that drive deal-making. The rewards are skewed to encourage making the deal whether it’s a good idea or not, which means, for the folks advising corporations on the wisdom of mergers and acquisitions, there are usually more good reasons to strike an agreement than to shelve it, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline.main: Buffett Casts a Wary Eye on Bankers

abstract: Giving small businesses an incentive to hire people is like giving someone a low interest loan to buy a bigger house they might not be able to afford.
snippet: Giving small businesses an incentive to hire people is like giving someone a low interest loan to buy a bigger house they might not be able to afford.
lead_paragraph: The Senate has passed a $15 billion package that is aimed at helping small businesses. There are two key parts. One is the extension of section 179 of the tax code, which allows up to $250,000 of capital expenditures to be expensed immediately instead of being depreciated over time. This will motivate some companies to make capital expenditures that will reduce their tax bills, which is good for the economy. The other part is the suspension of FICA payments for the rest of the year for new hires.

headline.main: $15 Billion but Not a Lot of Sense

abstract: Will Leitch, author of a toxic Roger Ebert piece, on how pushing “send” can come to be a very regrettable act.
snippet: Will Leitch, author of a toxic Roger Ebert piece, on how pushing “send” can come to be a very regrettable act.
lead_paragraph: Those of us who have written something freakishly mean — we are legion in an age of snark — and then come to gnaw the bone of regret can identify with Will Leitch. Writing at Deadspin, Mr. Leitch walks back the cat on a  missile he launched long ago at Roger Ebert that was entitled, more or less, “I Am Sick of Roger Ebert’s Fat (something even more nasty and less descriptive) Face.” Mr. Ebert, perhaps the most famous film critic of our age, has lost his voice and part of his face to thyroid cancer and was recently profiled in Esquire to very remarkable effect. Now that Mr. Ebert’s face is no longer fat, Mr. Letich has had time to contemplate his choice of targets — Mr. Ebert had shown him significant professional courtesies over the years — and writes about what it was like to use his keyboard to do something really dumb.

headline.main: Launching a Rocket That Becomes a Boomerang

abstract: The Avatar/Pocahontas mash-up to end all mash-ups.
snippet: The Avatar/Pocahontas mash-up to end all mash-ups.
lead_paragraph: As the Carpetbagger notes, we are deep into the silly season, with Oscar campaigning now veering into a debate over the military efficacy of “Hurt Locker.” The scurrilous tactics rarely change the outcome, so we prefer to walk on the sunny side of the awards season. To wit, when we first saw “Avatar,” it put us in the mind of “Dances with Wolves,” but the Internet has spoken and the designated analogue is actually “Pocahontas,” with a series of the inevitable mash-ups quickly following. But none, as Awards Daily points out, match this one for sheer brilliance of juxtaposition:

headline.main: Mashing Up the Navi

abstract: Medicare doesn’t cover everything. The typical married couple should expect to spend $197,000 on uninsured health care costs after turning 65, a new study finds.

lead_paragraph: The skyrocketing costs of health care aren’t just bad for Medicare’s solvency. They also spell trouble for the elderly themselves.

abstract: Under orders from the European Union to revise its budget, Greece has committed to new measures, but its finances continue to stoke bets against the euro, whose decline against the dollar has gladdened European exporters.

abstract: The Deal Professor examines a Delaware court decision validating Selectica’s poison pill in its dispute with Versata and he says the opinion, as broad as it is, is likely to weigh on activist shareholders in future proxy contests.
snippet: The Deal Professor examines a Delaware court decision validating Selectica’s poison pill in its dispute with Versata and he says the opinion, as broad as it is, is likely to weigh on activist shareholders in future proxy contests.
lead_paragraph: The long-awaited opinion in the Selectica case came out this week from Delaware Chancery Court. Vice Chancellor John W. Noble, in the 71-page opinion, validated the Selectica board’s decision to adopt a net operating loss poison pill and permit this pill to be set off after Versata intentionally crossed the pill’s threshold.

headline.main: Delaware Broadens Standards for Poison Pills

abstract: Jay Leno’s return to “The Tonight Show” Monday was watched by about 6.6 million viewers, up about 25 percent from his average viewership in the first quarter last year.

abstract: CF Industries’ surprise $4.7 billion bid for Terra Industries puts new pressure on the fertilizer maker, which has already accepted a $4.1 billion offer from Yara International.
snippet: CF Industries’ surprise $4.7 billion bid for Terra Industries puts new pressure on the fertilizer maker, which has already accepted a $4.1 billion offer from Yara International.
lead_paragraph: The surprise bid by CF Industries Holdings for Terra Industries has reignited the four-way war in the fertilizer industry, pushing valuations even higher and extending what could become one of the longest takeover battles ever.

abstract: Jared Bernstein, the chief economic adviser to the vice president, responds to an earlier Economix post by Edward Glaeser about how well-targeted stimulus spending has been.
snippet: Jared Bernstein, the chief economic adviser to the vice president, responds to an earlier Economix post by Edward Glaeser about how well-targeted stimulus spending has been.
lead_paragraph: In a post this morning titled “Wasted Stimulus,” the economist Edward L. Glaeser argued that a big chunk of stimulus spending wasn’t going to the areas that needed it most. Rather, he said, the money is being disproportionately spent on low-density areas that also happen to have low unemployment rates. Jared Bernstein, the chief economic adviser to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., has responded to Mr. Glaeser’s arguments.

headline.main: White House Response to Stimulus Criticisms

abstract: Pfizer is reportedly gearing up this week to bid 3 million euro ($4.08 billion) for Ratiopharm, a generic drug maker based in Germany.
snippet: Pfizer is reportedly gearing up this week to bid 3 million euro ($4.08 billion) for Ratiopharm, a generic drug maker based in Germany.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer is reportedly gearing up this week to bid 3 billion euro ($4.08 billion) for Ratiopharm, a generic drug maker based in Germany, according to Bloomberg News, which cited two unidentified people with knowledge of the talks. The move would pit Pfizer, the world’s largest drug maker, against Teva Pharmaceuticals Industries of Israel, the world’s largest generic drug maker, and Actvis of Iceland, another big generic drug maker, both of which are said to be interested in Ratiopharm, according to Bloomberg.

headline.main: Pfizer Said to Set Sights on German Drug Maker

Acquirers have paid an average of about 40 percent above market prices to get their quarry. Investors on the receiving end shouldn’t get too excited, though. Rather than reflecting ebullience, it looks as if healthy companies are pouncing on laggards while they can, Reuters Breakingviews says.

abstract: Merck’s Australian unit failed to warn a doctor about heart risks associated with its painkiller Vioxx, a court in Melbourne found.
snippet: Merck’s Australian unit failed to warn a doctor about heart risks associated with its painkiller Vioxx, a court in Melbourne found.
lead_paragraph: Merck’s Australian unit failed to warn a doctor about heart risks associated with its painkiller Vioxx, a court in Melbourne found, and might be ordered to pay almost 290,000 Australian dollars ($261,000) in damages. The Federal Court awarded the amount to Graeme R. Peterson, 59, in a case against Merck Sharpe & Dohme (Australia), the plaintiff’s law firm, Slater & Gordon, said Friday. The court found that Vioxx contributed to Mr. Peterson’s heart attack in 2003, according to the judgment. Merck said in a statement that it would appeal. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., withdrew Vioxx in 2004 after a study showed it doubled the risk of heart attacks and strokes.

headline.main: Australian Court Finds Damages in a Vioxx Case

lead_paragraph: As my colleague Lydia Polgreen writes, the upper house of India’s Parliament passed a bill on Tuesday that would amend the Constitution to reserve a third of the seats in India’s national and state legislatures for women. Such a provision may sound extreme, but it is nothing new: According to the Quota Project, about half of the world’s countries currently use some type of electoral quota for their national legislatures, in some cases enforced by political parties. (India has previously experimented with quotas for women in local elections.)

headline.main: A Female Parliamentary Majority in Just One Country: Rwanda

abstract: If I fired everyone who had complained at some point, there would be very few people here.
snippet: If I fired everyone who had complained at some point, there would be very few people here.
lead_paragraph: In my last post, I wrote about my desire to have happy people working for me. Perhaps I could have been clearer when I said that I fire unhappy people. Instead of unhappy, I probably should have said disrespectful (to others, not me), incompetent, unreasonable, undependable, irresponsible, unproductive, dysfunctional (I did say that one), angry, whiny or mean — and beyond a manager’s ability to repair (actually, I said that, too). I think most people understood the context of my post, but there were a few comments or questions that required a response.

headline.main: More on Happy Employees

lead_paragraph: Citigroup is moving from controlling damage to pursuing increased profits. Vikram S. Pandit, Citi’s chief executive, laid out ambitious targets for growth on Thursday afternoon, saying the bank’s return on assets should rise to 1.25 to 1.5 percent in the near future, from the current 1.15 percent. But the bank would not comment on when it would hit those goals or how it would deal with the billions of dollars of bad securities that remain as part of its Citi Holdings.

lead_paragraph: Komatsu, the Japanese heavy equipment maker, said Friday it expected sales in China to rise by half as the country’s 10 percent growth rate drives demand for resources like coal and iron ore. Sales in the year starting April 1 are expected to rise by 40 to 50 percent from the current year, Kazuhiko Iwata, the president of the company’s mining division, said. Mining machinery sales account for about 30 percent of Komatsu’s construction equipment division revenue, which is forecast to be 1.3 trillion yen ($14 billion) this year.

lead_paragraph: THE mouth of a giant monster, its razor-sharp teeth glaring overhead and its tongue forming a long red carpet, ushers visitors into the Tim Burton retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. Although the intentionally lighthearted chronicle of the filmmaker’s work received only mixed reviews when it opened in November, Mr. Burton’s fans don’t seem to care. More than 450,000 people have already attended the show, and by the time it closes on April 26, attendance is expected to exceed that of recent blockbusters like the museum’s “Van Gogh: The Colors of the Night” last year and “Dali: Painting and Film,” in 2008.

The resulting artworks soon went on tour throughout the country in a group show, “66 Signs of Neon.”

abstract: Men have borne the brunt of job losses in most developed countries.

lead_paragraph: We’ve written before about how men have borne the brunt of the job losses in this recession in the United States. This is largely because they are more likely to be employed in industries that are sensitive to the business cycle (like manufacturing and construction). Women are more disproportionately employed in industries that generally withstand downturns better (like health care, education and government work).

abstract: A swirl of new media at the South by Southwest conference.
snippet: A swirl of new media at the South by Southwest conference.
lead_paragraph: Decoder is in Austin, Texas, at the interactive portion of South by Southwest, or SxSW as it is known to its adherents and sponsors. The broad sweep of the conference arrays over music, film, and interactive media for nine days, and right now, we are in the early days, which is mostly deep programming for digital types. We decided to share some of the weekend events in one long post, which is known as a heave in journalistic parlance, but given some of what will take place in the wee hours on Sixth Street — a bar-strewn ribbon in the middle of the city that rival New Orleans’ Bourbon Street — let’s just call it a riff that is a little on the long side.

headline.main: South by Southwest’s Location-Based Allure

lead_paragraph: Talk about a wild ride. The amusement park operator Cedar Fair announced on Monday night that it had postponed Tuesday morning’s meeting for unit holders to vote on the company’s acquisition by Apollo Management, saying it wanted to provide more time to solicit votes and proxies. For those unit holders who have already made the trip up to Sandusky, Ohio, for the meeting, they will have a relatively long wait. The meeting is postponed until April 8. Perhaps Cedar Fair will placate these unit holders with some free amusement park tickets in the interim.

headline.main: Cedar Fair’s Last-Minute Change of Heart

abstract: The Lehman case shows how bankers exploited weaknesses in U.S. accounting standards — seemingly without objection from the firm’s auditor, Ernst & Young.

lead_paragraph: Lehman Brothers’ now notorious Repo 105 scheme depended on forum shopping. The investment bank wasn’t able to persuade its lawyers in the United States that the relevant repurchase agreements constituted real sales. So it routed them through its British subsidiary. That meant they came under the British legal system, and the law firm Linklaters was able to opine that the transactions counted as sales.

lead_paragraph: Each year millions of Americans with old, inefficient refrigerators in their kitchens buy new, energy saving ones. That may sound like an efficiency boon, but what’s vexing efficiency advocates is that an increasing number of consumers don’t actually get rid of the old fridge.

headline.main: Consumers Buy More Efficient Refrigerators, but Keep the Old Ones Humming

abstract: Shares of Palm Inc. fell the most in more than two years in Nasdaq trading after it forecast sales this quarter that were less than half of analysts’ estimates.

lead_paragraph: Shares of Palm Inc., creator of the Pre smartphone, fell the most in more than two years in Nasdaq trading after it forecast sales this quarter that were less than half of analysts’ estimates. Revenue in the period ending in May will be less than $150 million, the chief financial officer, Doug Jeffries, said after the close of trading on Thursday on Palm’s third-quarter conference call. That falls short of the $300 million average of estimates compiled by Bloomberg News. The company also reported its 11th consecutive quarterly loss. Shares of Palm, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., fell $1.65, or 29 percent, to $4, on Friday.

headline.main: Palm Stock Falls After a Disappointing Forecast

lead_paragraph: Yelp! What happens when an online review site itself becomes the subject of harsh public scrutiny? Such is the case of Yelp, the review site that carries the motto, “Real People. Real reviews.” In recent weeks, Yelp has been hit with three class-action lawsuits from businesses claiming that Yelp sales representatives tried to press the businesses into advertising by offering — or threatening — to manipulate reviews. Jeremy Stoppelman, a Yelp co-founder and its chief executive, has seen the tables of Web 2.0 turned against his company as angry business owners have taken to Internet boards to pan Yelp. A condensed version of a conversation with Mr. Stoppelman follows.

abstract: The big tax issue may be retirement account conversion and estate taxes, but there are some other changes and credits that can affect the tax bill for 2010.
snippet: The big tax issue may be retirement account conversion and estate taxes, but there are some other changes and credits that can affect the tax bill for 2010.
lead_paragraph: The discussion this tax season has been dominated by some big changes in tax and other laws. One allows some taxpayers to convert their regular retirement account to a Roth I.R.A., which would incur a tax bill now but the gains would then accumulate tax-free. Another is the expiration of the estate tax for 2010. And with the passage of the health care overhaul this week, there is now the prospect of surcharges for higher earners (though not until 2013).

headline.main: Some Tax Considerations to Keep in Mind for 2010

lead_paragraph: Directors at Credit Suisse borrowed a bit more money from the generous Swiss banking giant last year, the bank’s annual report shows. Nine directors accounted for about $23.7 million in loans (based on the current exchange rate of 93.4 cents to the Swiss franc), up from the seven directors who owed about $22.2 million at the end of 2008, according to the annual report, which was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday.

abstract: How will economic pressures influence Americans’ thinking on social issues like drug use, gambling, same-sex marriage and immigration?
snippet: How will economic pressures influence Americans’ thinking on social issues like drug use, gambling, same-sex marriage and immigration?
lead_paragraph: My colleague Jesse McKinley has a fascinating article today about how legal-marijuana advocates are promoting the fiscal virtues of their cause. Not coincidentally, another banned substance was legalized in the wake of major economic upheaval: alcohol, during the Great Depression. The “Noble Experiment” known as Prohibition ended in 1933, when a legalized alcohol market promised more job opportunities and additional sales tax revenues for governments under stress.

headline.main: Economic Desperation, Reshaping Morality

abstract: Toyota Motor said on Friday that it would idle three plants in France and Britain to reduce inventory amid recent recalls and a slump in European sales.
snippet: Toyota Motor said on Friday that it would idle three plants in France and Britain to reduce inventory amid recent recalls and a slump in European sales.
lead_paragraph: Toyota Motor said on Friday that it would idle three plants in France and Britain to reduce inventory amid recent recalls and a slump in European sales. The company will suspend output for four days in early April at its factory in Valenciennes, France, and for five days in May at its Burnaston and Deeside factories in Britain, according to a Toyota spokeswoman, Ririko Takeuchi. Toyota also plans to halt one of the two assembly lines at Burnaston for five days in early June, Ms. Takeuchi said.

headline.main: Toyota Cuts Production in Europe After Sales Slump

abstract: Because of a transcription error, the Boss feature last Sunday about Eric Hippeau, chief executive of The Huffington Post, misstated his description of the company’s growth rate. abstract: My only concern is that we have been so busy working on our sales challenges and upgrading the hardware in our data centers that we have not had time to focus on the logistics of the move.
snippet: My only concern is that we have been so busy working on our sales challenges and upgrading the hardware in our data centers that we have not had time to focus on the logistics of the move.
lead_paragraph: I started Backup My Info! from my small apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. After signing up a few clients, I hired my first engineer who worked with me in my apartment. I worked from my bedroom desk, and he worked from my kitchen table. I removed all of the pictures from my walls and replaced them with white boards that we used for strategy sessions. My floors were lined with duct tape that I used to hide and secure the network cords that ran between the bedroom and the kitchen. That year, my revenue reached $20,000, which was less than half my engineer’s salary. Looking back, I’m not sure how we did it. But necessity is necessity, right?

headline.main: How I Found My New Office Space With Twitter

Some have more education than others. When I started my company, I went through a series of surprises and shocks and the occasional nightmare. With all of the recent interest in entrepreneurship, I thought I would highlight six warning signs that you are about to be broadsided by one of the classic and inevitable struggles of business ownership. If you hear yourself saying these words, take a step back and think about what you’re doing. My hope is that by being more aware you will be better prepared.

lead_paragraph: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein examines the iPhone hack that was a winner at the 2010 Pwn2Own contest, held last week at the CanSecWest conference in Vancouver. She speaks with Ralf-Philipp Weinmann, a researcher at the University of Luxembourg’s Faculty of Science, Technology and Communication, who explains the basic strategy of the exploit. It took about 20 seconds, using the Safari browser, to seize control of the phone’s text message database, though as Mr. Weinmann explains, other personal information, like contacts, photos and e-mail and even iTunes files, could also be vulnerable. And only a firmware update can patch the vulnerability, he says.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: Hacking iPhones and Watching Mobile Movies
